newsitem.title: GERMANY: Period of consolidation of benefit to HMR - Hoechst.
newsitem.headline: Period of consolidation of benefit to HMR - Hoechst.

text.p: Hoechst Marion Roussel (HMR), the drugs unit of German chemicals and drugs group Hoechst AG, may be eyeing a period of consolidation even as the global drugs industry engages in massive restructurings, the group's chairman said on Monday.

"Unless something really attractive comes up as an acquisition, then two years of breathing space would do us (HMR) good," Hoechst AG chairman Juergen Dormann told the German newspaper Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung.

Dormann's comments come as the industry remains in flux with new partnerships, such as French group Rhone-Poulenc Rorer's bid for its U.S. drugs unit and Swiss group Roche AG's bid for Germany's Boehringer Mannheim.

Dormann spoke to the newspaper on the eve of Hoechst's biggest change to date on July 1 when Hoechst AG will officially become a strategic management holding company with no responsibility for operational business.
Hoechst's units, including the HMR drugs unit, will be separate legal entities and be responsible for their business.
Hoechst earlier announced plans to exit the generic drugs business and Dormann on Monday said the group would try "to anticipate developments." It is attempting to sell its U.S. generics unit Copley.
But sources close to the company have said there has been no real interest yet.

For the group's diagnostics business Behring Dade, Dormann said no date has yet been set for a bourse listing and that Behring was investigating whether or not it might consider taking a majority in the joint-venture between Behring and U.S. group Dade International.
Similarly, Hoechst is still considering the option of listing the industrial gases unit Messer Griesheim on the bourse next year.
Dormann repeated comments made at the company's annual festival that he expected a slightly improved operating profit in 1997.
